Introduction

Infectious urethritis is inflammation of the urethra caused by sexually transmitted pathogens, most commonly Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.  It is most prevalent in young, sexually active individuals and typically presents with dysuria and urethral discharge.  Although urethritis occurs in males and females, females typically present symptomatically with cervicitis (eg, vaginal discharge) or pelvic inflammatory disease (eg, pelvic pain) rather than isolated urethritis.



This article will focus mainly on urethritis in men (

).

Pathogenesis



Infectious urethritis occurs when viral or bacterial pathogens are introduced into the urethra through unprotected sexual contact.  These organisms invade the urethral mucosa and trigger an inflammatory response within the epithelium, resulting in urethral discomfort (eg, dysuria) and discharge.



There are 2 major categories of infectious urethritis, gonococcal and nongonococcal (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).

Gonococcal urethritis (GU)



  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae:  A sexually transmitted, intracellular, gram-negative diplococcus that adheres to and invades the urethral epithelium via pili, or hair-like proteins on the bacterial surface.  Antibodies generated by the host organism provide minimal immunity against future infections due to a high rate of antigenic variation in these surface pili.  This results in frequent reinfections in high-risk populations.

Nongonococcal urethritis (NGU)



May be caused by several other sexually transmitted bacterial or viral pathogens:



  • Chlamydia trachomatis:  The most common cause of NGU, this obligate intracellular gram-negative bacterium cannot grow outside of living cells and therefore cannot be cultured on standard laboratory media ("culture-negative urethritis").  In addition, C trachomatis lacks sufficient peptidoglycan in its cell wall, making it invisible on Gram stain.
  • Mycoplasma genitalium:  The second most common cause of NGU, this atypical bacterium lacks a cell wall and cannot be grown on culture.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis:  This motile, flagellated protozoan infects the epithelium of the urogenital tract, causing cell injury and inflammation.
  • Viruses are less common pathogens but may include herpes simplex virus and adenovirus.


Both GU and NGU infections can spread to upper reproductive organs, leading to epididymitis, prostatitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease (in females).

Risk factors



  • Unprotected sexual contact, especially with a new partner or multiple partners
  • Men who have sex with men (MSM)
  • History of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
  • Young age (highest incidence at age 20-24)
  • Immunosuppression (eg, HIV)

Clinical presentation



Some patients with urethritis are asymptomatic.  NGU infections are more likely to have mild or no symptoms and often go undiagnosed, whereas GU infections tend to cause more noticeable symptoms.  Symptomatic patients with urethritis typically have the following:



  • Dysuria
  • Urethral discharge:  May be mucopurulent or watery.
    • Purulent, thick, yellow-green discharge suggests N gonorrhoeae.
    • Scant, mucoid, or watery discharge suggest NGU infections (eg, C trachomatis, M genitalium).
  • Discomfort at the urethral meatus (eg, irritation, burning, itching).
  • Erythema or swelling of the urethral meatus.


Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) are uncommon unless the infection spreads to adjacent structures (eg, epididymis, prostate).

Differential diagnosis



Several conditions can mimic infectious urethritis:



  • Acute cystitis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Infection confined to the bladder causes dysuria, urgency, and frequency, but urethral discharge is absent.
  • Acute bacterial prostatitis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ):  Patients are typically ill-appearing and have dysuria, pelvic/perineal pain, voiding difficulty (eg, hesitancy, dribbling), and systemic symptoms (eg, fever, chills).  On examination, the prostate is edematous and tender to palpation.
  • Epididymitis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
    ):  Characterized by unilateral testicular pain and swelling as well as focal tenderness on the posterior aspect of the testis.
  • Noninfectious urethritis:  Urethral inflammation may be caused by chemical irritants (eg, spermicides) or trauma (eg, catheterization).  Laboratory testing can differentiate infectious from noninfectious etiologies.

Diagnosis



Urethritis should be suspected in patients with dysuria, urethral discharge, and risk factors for STI.



The diagnosis of infectious urethritis is made when â‰¥1 of the following are present:



  • Purulent or mucopurulent penile discharge
  • â‰¥2 leukocytes per field on urethral swab Gram stain
  • Positive leukocyte esterase on urine dipstick or â‰¥10 leukocytes/hpf on urinalysis


Identification of the underlying organism is generally made with nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of a urethral swab or first-void urine sample (collected from the first part of urination without prior cleaning of the meatus).

Laboratory evaluation



The laboratory evaluation for infectious urethritis typically begins with a screening urinalysis to assess for leukocyte esterase or â‰¥10 leukocytes/hpf, which supports the diagnosis of infectious urethritis.  However, the most important step is identifying the causative organism, which is essential for proper management.  This is best accomplished using:



  • Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT):  This is the gold standard for diagnosis.  It can be conducted on a urethral swab or first-void urine, which is less uncomfortable for the patient.  all patients with evidence of infectious urethritis should undergo testing for gonorrhea and chlamydia because these are the most common pathogens.


Because it often takes 24-72 hours to obtain a NAAT result, Gram staining can be performed to more rapidly diagnose N gonorrhoeae while awaiting NAAT results.  Gram stain in these cases often shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci and multiple polymorphonuclear leukocytes (

image 1
).  In contrast, C trachomatis cannot be seen on Gram stain due to the lack of peptidoglycan in its cell wall.  Given the high rate of gonorrhea and chlamydia co-infection, patients diagnosed with gonorrhea by Gram stain should still undergo NAAT testing for chlamydia.



Additional testing may include:



  • HIV and syphilis screening:  Due to high co-infection rates.
  • NAAT for T vaginalis and/or M genitalium:  Testing for these less common infections is reasonable if there is adequate clinical suspicion (eg, diagnosed in a partner), a high local prevalence of disease, or when patients have persistent urethritis symptoms after receiving usual management for gonorrhea and chlamydia.
  • Herpes simplex virus testing:  May be obtained if there are penile vesicles or ulcerations.
  • Urine culture with antibiotic sensitivity testing:  Antibiotic-resistant gonorrhea is a growing concern, so culture-based therapy adjustments may be necessary.  Culture may also reveal other urinary tract pathogens (eg, Escherichia coli) that require treatment.

Imaging studies



Imaging is not routinely required unless complications of urethritis are suspected.  However, testicular ultrasonography is used if epididymitis (eg, hyperemia of the epididymis) is suspected.  Transrectal ultrasonography is used occasionally to evaluate for complicated prostatitis (eg, abscess).

Management



To reduce sequelae (eg, prostatitis, epididymitis) and risk of transmission, infectious urethritis is treated empirically while awaiting NAAT results.  Gonorrhea and chlamydia co-infections are common, so empiric treatment should include coverage for both pathogens:



  • N gonorrhoeae:  ceftriaxone
  • C trachomatis:  doxycycline OR azithromycin (single dose) if medication adherence is a concern


Treatment for other infectious organisms (eg, M genitalium, T vaginalis) should be provided based on clinical suspicion and/or positive NAAT results.



Reinfection is common and should be suspected when symptoms resolve completely with treatment and then reoccur after a short period.  Most cases of reinfection are triggered by intercourse with a new sexual partner who is infected or a lack of treatment in an ongoing sexual partner.

Prevention



Patients are advised to abstain from sexual activity for 7 days after antibiotic treatment is completed and have all sexual partners tested and treated to prevent reinfection.  Counseling about the importance of safe sex practices (eg, condom use) and routine STI screening is essential for future prevention.

Complications and prognosis



Most patients with urethritis have an excellent prognosis.  Complications are rare if the condition is treated early, but untreated infections can cause infectious complications, including epididymitis or prostatitis, urethral strictures, and infertility.



Rarely, patients with GU can develop disseminated gonococcal infection, which presents with migratory polyarthralgias, painless skin lesions (typically pustules), tenosynovitis, and fever.



In addition, Reiter syndrome (associated with C trachomatis infection) can occur.  Patients typically have acute mono- or oligoarticular arthritis, usually in a lower extremity, arising days to weeks following an infection.  The classic triad includes arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis (ie, "can't see, can't pee, can't climb a tree").

Summary



Infectious urethritis is inflammation of the urethra due to sexually transmitted infections.  Although some patients are asymptomatic, the typical presentation involves dysuria and urethral discharge.  Diagnosis is confirmed with nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) and treatment is antibiotics.  Empiric treatment should be provided prior to NAAT results and cover both Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis because these are the most common pathogens and co-infection is common.
